job_title: Talent Acquisition Partner in London, England
pros: benefits, technology, innovation and good colleagues
cons:
Endless reorganizations followed by rounds of redundancies, no work-life balance at all and poor management . 
GE pretends to be a meritocracy and claims that you "own your career" but the reality is quite different- favoritism is abundant. And because reorganisation is a constant, there is a valid excuse to promote the "yes" people.
Work-life balance is non existent- most people work long hours, answer emails over the weekend and at night. In TA you are constantly struggling between endless and useless team meetings, pipelining for roles that may never open, communicating with candidates on roles that were open, marked as urgent and then cancelled or put on hold; attending training on new tools, lean workouts and still be expected to volunteer for additional projects. Not to mention the monthly KPI reviews- when you need to justify why you are not identifying more diverse candidates and not doing more training on Linkedin!

review_title: A company with a great mission and essential to our world, but sadly with sometime poor local sites
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Livingston, Scotland
pros:
GE does the most important work in this world and gets very little credit and accolade for what it can and does achieve. You have electricity when you flick the switch, you have GE to thank for that. Greener energy? Those big windmill, guess who? GE that is who!

A lot of talented and smart engineers in there. A lot of people taking great pride in tackling the challenges out there.
cons: No leadership and no career path... at least for the offices based in Scotland central belt. You would think with such a large group, opportunities would be abound. Sadly, no. Lots of silos, lots of in-fighting about budgets. Very rigid structures and frustrating "managers" to deal with. Some say it is because they are badly treated and therefore it trickles down. Well over the years, I have met and kept in touch with various GE folks (some managers themselves) around the world and the barriers I have experienced seem pretty localised. So much so that if you mention the name of the site I am based from, the reply from employees based elsewhere might often be: "oh, I feel sorry for you".

review_title: No longer proud to work for GE
pros: A large multinational corporation operating across a number of sectors.
cons:
I have been with GE for over 10 years. I was previously VERY happy and proud to work for GE, but this is no longer the case. When it comes to employees that are below Executive Level, my personal impression is that the company is focusing mainly on cost cutting and cares very little about the impact on employees’ lives in doing so. 

I am referring to the pension scheme changes that will apply as of January 2022 to UK GE employees with long service [10 - 25 years GE service]. The pension changes imposed are devastatingly life changing [expected pension pot size for those who choose to remain with GE, or have no real choice - will be slashed] with very little by way compensation.

pros: Good work - life balance. Lots of flexibility to manage workload. Challenging work and always learning something new. Work with a lot of smart people. Latest CEO has company back on track.
cons: Former CEO made terrible business decisions that nearly drove the company into the ground. Working level employees constantly being told they aren’t good enough when the poor business position was due to the decisions of the CEO and upper management. Constant layoffs and threats of more layoffs really wears one down and it has been deflating to see so many good people laid off because of the former CEO’s bad decisions and politics. Layoffs used to be based on performance, the more recent ones were political (poor performers protected by labor laws in their home country versus high performers being let go because their home country did not have the same labor protections). So despite the fact that I’ve overall rated the company on the high side, I don’t think I would recommend a friend to work at GE.

pros:
*Diversified in multiple industries
*Limited opportunities to move between different GE businesses
*Pay is decent
*Company culture used to be very positive and performance-based
*Renewed focus on lean and operations seems to be paying off
*Strong (though selective) focus on integrity and compliance
*Generally strong in engineering and operations
cons:
*GE is currently heavily white male, and senior leadership and HR seem to be pursuing a "purge" of white males using several tactics:
 ....*Have established racial and gender quotas for hiring and promotions
 ....*Have regular Problem Solving Reports (PSR's) and Action Plans explicitly intended to reduce the proportion of white male employees in the company
 ....*The standard annual performance review includes a "9-blocker" where all employees are ranked against one another; in this 9-blocker, all employees are highlighted in a special color for extra consideration, except for white US males (females highlighted in pink, US non-white highlighted in blue, international highlighted in green)
 ....*Regularly promote "Affinity Groups" to celebrate all groups but Caucasians and males
 ....*Have cancelled all mid-career programs and tuition reimbursement
 ....*Have cancelled the pension and generally reduced benefits
 ....*Continue to focus resources on early career development, and hiring non-white-males to replace the ones they are scaring off
 ....*White males are generally not hired or promoted except as a last resort (which still happens often, simply due to the sheer number of qualified white male applicants)
*This creates a fairly toxic culture, where white males feel they are viewed as "the problem" and non-white-males feel that they are viewed as "diversity hires" (an incredible disservice to all of our amazing, talented, hard-working employees)
*Ironically, the company is largely led by white males at the executive level, and they wholeheartedly support the purge of other white males beneath them (presumably because it is a great PR move for them, and it keeps them safe)
*The company preaches integrity and candor, but everyone knows that they are not allowed to question the company's new focus on discriminating against its own employees based on gender and skin color.
*Not surprisingly, GE currently has a problem with attrition (including with "diverse" employees), as many subject matter experts flee the company
